questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE?

answers.A: MIMO provides diversity and multiplexing while SIMO/MISO only provide diversity
answers.B: SIMO/MISO provide diversity and multiplexing while MIMO only provides diversity
answers.C: MIMO provides only multiplexing gain while SIMO/MISO provide only diversity gain
answers.D: All provide both multiplexing and diversity

explanations.A: Correct! MIMO can provide both diversity and multiplexing gain, while SIMO/MISO primarily offer diversity gain.
explanations.B: Incorrect. SIMO/MISO do not provide multiplexing gain.
explanations.C: Incorrect. MIMO can provide both gains, not just multiplexing.
explanations.D: Incorrect. SIMO/MISO do not inherently support multiplexing gain.

questions.question: How is rank(H) related to the number of antennas at the transmitter and receiver?

explanations.A: Incorrect. Rank(H) is not simply the sum of the number of antennas.
explanations.B: Correct! The maximum possible rank of the channel matrix is min(Mt, Mr).
explanations.C: Incorrect. The maximum is the minimum of the two antenna counts, not the maximum.
explanations.D: Incorrect. This expression is not meaningful in this context.

questions.question: The matrices U and V in the SVD of the MIMO channel matrix are...

explanations.A: Correct! In SVD, U and V are complex unitary matrices.
explanations.B: Incorrect. Hermitian matrices are equal to their conjugate transpose, which is not the case here.
explanations.C: Incorrect. They are generally complex, not purely real.
explanations.D: Incorrect. This property does not depend on the specific channel realization.

questions.question: How many non-zero entries will the matrix S have in the SVD of H?

explanations.A: Incorrect. The number of rows in S is not the same as the number of non-zero entries.
explanations.B: Incorrect. The number of transmit antennas does not directly determine this.
explanations.C: Correct! The number of non-zero singular values equals rank(H).
explanations.D: Incorrect. Mr × Mt is the total number of elements, not non-zero singular values.

questions.question: Which condition must be met for spatial multiplexing to work effectively?

answers.A: The number of receive antennas must be less than the number of transmit antennas
answers.B: The channel must be frequency flat
answers.C: The MIMO channel matrix must be full rank

explanations.A: Incorrect. Having fewer receive antennas can actually limit spatial multiplexing.
explanations.B: Incorrect. Spatial multiplexing can also work in frequency-selective channels with proper processing.
explanations.C: Correct! Full rank ensures multiple independent spatial streams for multiplexing.
explanations.D: Incorrect. Antenna directionality is not the primary factor.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about spatial multiplexing is true?

answers.B: It only works with single antenna systems
answers.C: It increases capacity linearly with the number of antennas under ideal conditions
answers.D: It is independent of channel state information

explanations.A: Incorrect. Spatial multiplexing improves data rate, not necessarily reliability.
explanations.C: Correct! Under ideal full-rank and high-SNR conditions, capacity scales linearly with the number of antennas.
explanations.D: Incorrect. CSI is often needed at least at the receiver for decoding.

questions.question: Which of the following are TRUE about the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff?

answers.A: MIMO systems only provide multiplexing gain
answers.B: Trying to achieve diversity gain will lead to loss in multiplexing gain
answers.C: Diversity gain can be achieved without any loss in multiplexing gain
answers.D: Diversity gain will enhance multiplexing gain

explanations.A: Incorrect. MIMO can provide both gains, but not simultaneously at maximum levels.
explanations.B: Correct! Increasing diversity generally reduces achievable multiplexing gain due to the tradeoff.
explanations.C: Incorrect. There is usually a tradeoff — increasing one reduces the other.
explanations.D: Incorrect. Diversity and multiplexing gains compete rather than enhance each other.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a drawback of spatial multiplexing in MIMO?

answers.B: It degrades performance in correlated channels
answers.C: It reduces data rate in high SNR

explanations.A: Incorrect. This is indeed a drawback — rich scattering is often required.
explanations.B: Incorrect. Channel correlation can indeed reduce spatial multiplexing performance.
explanations.C: Correct! In high SNR, spatial multiplexing actually increases data rate, not reduces it.
explanations.D: Incorrect. Receiver complexity is indeed a drawback.
